responsible_party: Somerset County Commissioners
stakeholders: Residents and government entities in Somerset County, including potential buyers of surplus property and local community members affected by property sales.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business support or failure reduction; it primarily concerns the sale of county surplus properties.

Title: Agriculture - Invasive Plant Species - Regulation (Biodiversity and Agriculture Protection Act)
Synopsis: Altering the regulatory approach for controlling invasive plant species in the State, including repealing certain provisions of law relating to a two-tiered regulatory approach and requiring the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a list of prohibited invasive plants by regulation in a certain manner on or before October 1, 2024; establishing certain protocols for assessing certain nonnative plants and determining whether those plants are invasive or whether the plants may be placed on a certain watch list; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland's regulations on invasive plant species by establishing a new regulatory framework, including creating a list of prohibited invasive plants, protocols for assessing nonnative plants, and procedures for classification, disposal, and sale restrictions.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture and the Invasive Plants Advisory Committee
stakeholders: Nurseries, plant dealers, landscapers, environmental agencies, and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes provisions to phase in regulations considering economic impacts on nurseries and landscapers, aiming to support small businesses while managing invasive species.

Title: Public Health - Opioid Restitution Advisory Council and Fund - Revisions
Synopsis: Requiring the Secretary of Health to present decisions for the allocations of money from the Opioid Restitution Fund to the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to post on the Department's website certain information regarding allocations of money from the Fund; and requiring the Department to report to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 1, 2024, on the best process for making the expenditures of all opioid settlement agreements accessible to the public.
bill_summary: The bill revises the administration and reporting requirements for Maryland's Opioid Restitution Fund, including how decisions on fund allocations are made and communicated, and mandates annual reporting by political subdivisions on fund expenditures.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health and the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council.
stakeholders: Individuals with substance use disorders, community-based recovery organizations, and residents of jurisdictions receiving funds from the Opioid Restitution Fund.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it supports community organizations and public health programs that may indirectly benefit local economies.

Title: Principal Departments - Individuals With Limited English Proficiency - Access to Public Services
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before July 1, 2025, the principal departments of the Executive Branch to fully implement certain provisions of law requiring equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that all principal departments of the Maryland Executive Branch fully implement laws ensuring equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency by July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Disabilities and other principal departments of the Maryland Executive Branch
stakeholders: Individuals with limited English proficiency in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on public service access and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: State Personnel - Maryland Department of Health - Pay Rates
Synopsis: Increasing the number of certain bargaining units for the purpose of specifying certain pay rates for certain employees of the Maryland Department of Health; and requiring that the pay rates of certain Department employees who are in certain bargaining units and who work at certain facilities be equal to certain pay rates of the employees who work at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital.
bill_summary: The bill increases pay rates for certain Maryland Department of Health employees, especially those working at the Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents, by aligning their pay with higher rates at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital, and establishes pay grade adjustments for employees in specific bargaining units.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Employees of the Maryland Department of Health working at Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents and Clifton T. Perkins Hospital, and the patients they serve.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily affects government employees and does not have a direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Coverage for the Treatment of Obesity - Required Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to study the impact of requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide comprehensive coverage for the treatment of obesity, including coverage for intensive behavioral therapy, bariatric surgery, and FDA-approved antiobesity medication; and requiring the Department to report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to study the impact of mandating comprehensive coverage for obesity treatment under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program, including therapies like behavioral therapy, bariatric surgery, and FDA-approved medications, and to report findings by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Medicaid recipients and individuals with obesity in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but by potentially reducing healthcare costs and improving health outcomes, it may indirectly support economic stability.

Title: Montgomery County – Subdivision Plats – Conditions PG/MC 111–24
Synopsis: Providing that the Montgomery County Planning Board may tentatively approve a subdivision plat subject to specified conditions; and providing for the approval and submission of a certain subdivision plat to the county land records.
bill_summary: The bill allows the Montgomery County Planning Board to tentatively approve subdivision plats with conditions before improvements are completed, and specifies that approval is contingent on completing those conditions before final approval and recording.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Planning Board
stakeholders: Developers and residents involved in subdivision development in Montgomery County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By streamlining the subdivision approval process with conditional tentative approvals, the bill may reduce delays and costs for small developers, potentially lowering their failure rate.

Title: Environment - Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reductions - Manufacturers
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "manufacturing" for purposes of certain greenhouse gas emissions reduction requirements to exclude the production of cement; altering the application of certain provisions of law regarding the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing sector to apply only to persons that engaged in manufacturing in 2023; requiring the Department of the Environment to make certain considerations and consult with certain stakeholders related to the regulation of the production of cement; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies Maryland's greenhouse gas emissions reduction laws by excluding cement production from the definition of manufacturing and adjusting regulations to only apply to manufacturers active in 2023. It also requires the Department of the Environment to consider specific factors and consult stakeholders when regulating cement production.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Manufacturers, especially cement producers, and stakeholders involved in greenhouse gas emissions reduction efforts.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to limit regulatory costs on manufacturers, including cement producers, which could help reduce the risk of small business failure by preventing excessive compliance costs.

Title: Agriculture - Food Processing Residuals Utilization Permit - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing a food processing residuals utilization permit; prohibiting a person from utilizing food processing residuals in the State unless the person obtains a permit; requiring the Department of Agriculture to provide a certain notice and information to certain persons in a county where food processing residuals will be stored; establishing the Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund; authorizing a representative of the Department to enter and inspect any site where food processing residuals are utilized; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a permit system for the utilization of food processing residuals, including industrial sludge, in agricultural operations in Maryland. It sets regulations for permits, site inspections, record-keeping, and safety standards, and creates a Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund to support these activities.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
stakeholders: Farmers, food processing companies, commercial haulers, and local communities in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides a structured regulatory framework and permits for food processing residuals utilization, which can help small businesses in agriculture and food processing to operate legally and safely, potentially reducing failure rates.

Title: Environment - Delegated Authorities - Well and Septic Program Permits
Synopsis: Requiring a local health department or county government to which the Department of the Environment has delegated authority to administer a septic and well program to submit, by December 1, 2024, a schedule of review times for certain well and septic program permits for approval; and requiring a local health department or county government to submit well and septic program permit data to the Department for review beginning 3 months after the original schedule submission approved by the Department and every 3 months thereafter.
bill_summary: The bill requires local health departments or county governments with delegated authority to submit a schedule of review times for well and septic permits to the Maryland Department of the Environment by December 1, 2024, and to regularly submit permit data every three months thereafter.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and local health departments or county governments with delegated authority
stakeholders: Local health departments, county governments, residents and businesses involved in well and septic system installation and maintenance
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to streamline permit review processes and improve data sharing, which could help small businesses involved in well and septic system services operate more efficiently and reduce failure rates.

Title: Washington County Board of Education - Members - Residency Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring that a member of the Washington County Board of Education be a resident of Washington County for at least 6 months and the State for at least 12 months immediately preceding the date the member takes office; and requiring members of the county board to maintain a primary residence in Washington County during their term.
bill_summary: The bill requires members of the Washington County Board of Education to be residents of Washington County and the State for specified periods before taking office, and mandates that they maintain a primary residence in Washington County during their term.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of Education and the Maryland State Board of Education
stakeholders: Residents of Washington County, including students, parents, educators, and local community members
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on education board residency requirements.

Title: Consumer Protection - Consumer Council - Name Change
Synopsis: Changing the name of the Consumer Council in the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General to the Consumer Protection Commission.
bill_summary: The bill changes the name of the Consumer Council to the Consumer Protection Commission, modifies its structure, and clarifies its functions and funding provisions.
responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Consumers, consumer advocacy groups, businesses, and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates but may indirectly support fair trade practices.

Title: Maryland Department of Labor – Unemployment Insurance – Study on Actively Seeking Work Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Labor, on or before December 1, 2024, to conduct a study on the actively seeking work requirement of the unemployment insurance system in the State and other states to evaluate the effects of ghosting on actively seeking work requirements and report on the study to the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to conduct a study on the actively seeking work requirements for unemployment insurance, including the impact of ghosting (failing to attend scheduled interviews or maintain contact) and how other states verify these requirements. The study aims to evaluate current verification methods and explore potential improvements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Unemployment insurance claimants, employers, and the Maryland Department of Labor
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates but may improve the unemployment insurance system's effectiveness, which could indirectly benefit small businesses.

Title: Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network to identify and analyze options for establishing and maintaining an open access science, technology, and innovation network or hub of citizen scientists and experts in science, technology, and industry for certain purposes; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Workgroup to develop a science and technology best practices and innovation network in Maryland, focusing on creating a digital platform for experts and fostering collaboration and information exchange.
responsible_party: University of Maryland, Baltimore County (provides staff for the Workgroup)
stakeholders: Scientists, technology experts, higher education institutions, community organizations, and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small businesses or their failure rates, but the development of a science and technology network could indirectly support innovation and business success.

Title: Office of the Attorney General - Investigative Authority - Health Care Fraud
Synopsis: Authorizing the Office of the Attorney General, a Deputy Attorney General, or an Assistant Attorney General to issue a subpoena to a person to produce certain materials, answer written interrogatories, and give certain testimony in furtherance of an ongoing health care fraud investigation under the Maryland False Health Claims Act or other civil authority; authorizing the Attorney General to report a failure to obey a certain subpoena to the circuit court with jurisdiction over the matter; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Office of the Attorney General to issue subpoenas and conduct investigations related to healthcare fraud, waste, and abuse within the Maryland Department of Health, including the authority to subpoena evidence, administer oaths, and take depositions. It also establishes procedures for court enforcement of subpoenas and investigations.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General of Maryland
stakeholders: Healthcare providers, patients, and organizations involved in healthcare in Maryland, especially those suspected of healthcare fraud, waste, or abuse.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on healthcare fraud investigations and does not directly address small business failure rates, so its impact on small business failure is minimal or indirect.

Title: Montgomery County - Clerk of the Circuit Court - Plat Recordation PG/MC 110-24
Synopsis: Authorizing a plat in Montgomery County to be drawn, recorded, and maintained in electronic form in a manner approved by the State Archivist.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Montgomery County to draw, record, and maintain subdivision plats in electronic form, approved by the State Archivist, and updates recordation procedures.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Clerk of the Circuit Court and the State Archivist
stakeholders: Property owners, surveyors, and county officials involved in land subdivision and recordation in Montgomery County.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's impact on small business failure rates is minimal, as it primarily updates record-keeping procedures for land plats.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Average Final Compensation - Compensation Adjustments
Synopsis: Establishing that certain adjustments to compensation may not be considered an extraordinary salary increase when determining the average final compensation of a member in the State Retirement and Pension System; and requiring a member to submit certain information to the State Retirement Agency in a certain manner at the time of retirement.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies that certain salary adjustments, such as promotions or market-based adjustments, are not considered extraordinary salary increases when calculating a member's average final compensation for retirement benefits in Maryland's State Retirement and Pension System.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, particularly those approaching retirement or receiving salary adjustments
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to retirement system calculations and salary adjustments for public employees.

Title: Correctional Officers' Retirement System - Membership
Synopsis: Altering membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System to include certain employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Department of Health; requiring the State Retirement and Pension System to transfer the creditable service of employees transferred into the Correctional Officers' Retirement System under the Act unless the employee elects not to transfer service on or before June 1, 2025; authorizing certain employees to elect not to transfer service; etc.
bill_summary: The bill expands membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System to include certain employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Health, allows for credit for unused sick leave, and adjusts retirement and service transfer rules for eligible employees.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Department of Health, and other eligible correctional and health department employees in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts government employees and does not directly target small businesses, so its potential to reduce small business failure is minimal.

Title: Public Health – Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program – Recovery of Funding
Synopsis: Altering the number of years after completion of a project funded in part by a grant of the Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program after which the State may recover funding under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the recovery period for funds provided to federally qualified health centers in Maryland, extending the time frame from 15 to 30 years for property ownership and from 15 to 15 years for leasing, after which the state can recover funds if the property ceases to be a health center or is transferred to ineligible parties.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Public Works and the Secretary of Health
stakeholders: Federally qualified health centers, property owners, and the Maryland public who rely on these health services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on health centers and property transfer regulations, not directly on small businesses, so it has minimal impact on small business failure rates.

Title: State Officers and Employees – Required Surety Bonds – Insurance Policies Authorized
Synopsis: Altering the requirements that certain officers and employees of the State be covered by certain surety bonds to allow the officers and employees to be covered by certain insurance policies; transferring certain duties and responsibilities of the Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee to the State Treasurer; and repealing certain provisions of law related to the approval, form, and record of certain surety bonds required for certain officers and employees of the State.
bill_summary: The bill allows certain Maryland state officers and employees to be covered by insurance policies instead of surety bonds, and transfers related duties to the State Treasurer. It updates legal requirements for bond and insurance coverage across various state agencies.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Treasurer's Office is responsible for implementing the programs.
stakeholders: Maryland state officers and employees, including officials in various state agencies and departments.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's impact on small business failure rates is indirect, primarily through administrative efficiency and risk management improvements for state agencies.

Title: State Employees - Paid Sick Leave - Certificate of Illness or Disability Signed by a Licensed Clinical Professional Counselor
Synopsis: Authorizing a licensed clinical professional counselor to sign a certificate of illness or disability when a State employee uses sick leave for 5 or more consecutive workdays.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes licensed clinical professional counselors to sign certificates of illness or disability for Maryland state employees who take sick leave beyond five days, allowing them to provide documentation for extended sick leave.
responsible_party: Maryland State Personnel and Pensions Department
stakeholders: Maryland state employees who may need extended sick leave and licensed clinical professional counselors
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Frederick County - School Construction Master Plan Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup; and requiring the Workgroup to comprehensively evaluate all school facility needs in Frederick County and report its findings and recommendations to certain Frederick County officials, the Interagency Commission on School Construction and the Frederick County House and Senate Delegations by December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup to evaluate school facility needs, explore solutions for funding and maintaining schools, and report findings and recommendations by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Frederick County Board of Education and the Frederick County government
stakeholders: Students, parents, educators, and residents of Frederick County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure, but potential cost-saving and cost-sharing solutions could indirectly benefit local businesses involved in school construction and maintenance.

Title: Boundary of the Frederick County Soil Conservation District - Alteration
Synopsis: Establishing the Frederick County Soil Conservation District to include the Catoctin Soil Conservation District and the Frederick Soil Conservation District.
bill_summary: The bill alters the boundaries of the Frederick County Soil Conservation District to include the Catoctin Soil Conservation District and the Frederick Soil Conservation District, effectively expanding the district's coverage within Frederick County.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
stakeholders: Landowners and water users within Frederick County, including farmers and conservation agencies
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on boundary adjustments for soil conservation districts and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Washington County - Public Facilities Bonds
Synopsis: Authorizing and empowering the County Commissioners of Washington County to borrow not more than $50,000,000 in order to finance the construction, improvement, or development of certain public facilities in Washington County and to effect such borrowing by the issuance and sale at public or private sale of its general obligation bonds; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Washington County to issue up to $50 million in bonds to finance public facilities, water and sewer projects, and volunteer fire department facilities, including emergency equipment. It also allows the county to make loans to volunteer fire departments for emergency-related equipment and facilities, and to issue refunding bonds.
responsible_party: Washington County Government and County Commissioners
stakeholders: Residents of Washington County, volunteer fire departments, and users of public facilities and infrastructure in Washington County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on public infrastructure and emergency services funding, with no direct provisions targeting small business failure reduction.

Title: Prince George's County and Montgomery County - The Washington Suburban Transit Commission Reform Act PG/MC 103-24
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of Transportation's designee to attend meetings of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors on behalf of the Secretary when the Secretary is not available; authorizing the Washington Suburban Transit Commission to reappoint a certain appointee to be a principal member of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors; etc.
bill_summary: The bill reforms the governance and operations of the Washington Suburban Transit Commission in Prince George's and Montgomery Counties, including clarifying appointment procedures, powers, and the ability to reappoint members to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors.
responsible_party: Washington Suburban Transit Commission and the Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Residents and commuters in Prince George's County and Montgomery County who use transit services
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on transit governance and does not directly address small business support or failure reduction.

Title: Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission - Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program - Expansion PG/MC 101-24
Synopsis: Expanding the Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program to include certain sewer pipes and diagnostic actions; altering the maximum amount of a loan that may be made under the Program from $5,000 to $10,000; altering the total amount of loans that the Program may provide or have outstanding from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000; and increasing to $200,000 the amount of funding through fiscal year 2034  which the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission must include for the Program in the Commission's budget.
bill_summary: The bill expands the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission's Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program to include sewer pipes and diagnostic actions, increases the maximum loan amount from $5,000 to $10,000, and raises the total outstanding loan limit from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000. It also adjusts funding and budget requirements for the program.
responsible_party: Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC)
stakeholders: Residential customers with malfunctioning water or sewer service pipes in the WSSC service area
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily targets residential customers and does not directly impact small businesses, so its potential to reduce small business failure is minimal.

Title: Armed Forces - Support of Military Families and Addition of Space Force
Synopsis: Adding the Space Force to certain provisions of law related to the armed forces; authorizing military spouses and residents of the State who are members of the National Guard of another state or a reserve component of the armed forces to terminate certain contracts at any time after the date the service member receives certain military orders to relocate; altering the definition of a "military-connected student" for purposes of the Purple Star Schools Program; and authorizing the Governor to make certain posthumous awards.
bill_summary: The bill expands Maryland laws to include the Space Force in various military-related provisions, allows military spouses and residents to terminate certain contracts after receiving military orders to relocate, updates the definition of 'military-connected student' to include the Space Force and members of other states' National Guards, and authorizes posthumous military commissions and promotions.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Maryland State Department of Education, Maryland Military Department, and other relevant state agencies.
stakeholders: Military service members, military spouses, military families, students connected to military families, and residents of Maryland who are members of the National Guard or reserve components.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides protections for military families and service members, which can reduce disruptions and financial burdens, potentially decreasing small business failures related to military relocations and service-related issues.

Title: Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup to study certain standards related to EV charging stations; and requiring the Workgroup to report its framework and recommendations to the Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee and the House Economic Matters Committee on or before November 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to develop regulations for the retail use of electric vehicle supply equipment in Maryland, including standards for reliability, payment options, labeling, and customer support, with the goal of improving EV charging infrastructure.
responsible_party: The Public Service Commission, in consultation with the Office of the Comptroller and other state agencies.
stakeholders: Electric vehicle owners, EV service providers, and the general public using EV charging stations in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's regulations aim to standardize and improve EV charging infrastructure, which could support small businesses involved in EV charging services by providing clear standards and reliability requirements.

Title: Highways – Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program to create a system of supplemental guide signs to direct motorists to eligible individual attractions by directing the motorists first to groups of attractions; requiring the State Highway Administration and the Department of Commerce to develop standards and procedures for determining the eligibility of an attraction for a sign; requiring the Administration to notify certain committees of the General Assembly at least 30 days before amending the Program; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program to create a system of signs directing motorists to eligible attractions, managed by the Maryland State Highway Administration in collaboration with the Department of Commerce.
responsible_party: Maryland State Highway Administration in collaboration with the Department of Commerce.
stakeholders: Tourists and visitors to Maryland attractions, local attractions, and the general public.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program supports local attractions by providing signage, which can increase visibility and visitor numbers, potentially reducing the risk of business failure.

Title: Baltimore City Sheriff - Staffing
Synopsis: Increasing from one to three the number of assistant sheriffs required to be appointed by the Baltimore City Sheriff; authorizing the Baltimore City Sheriff to appoint social workers and any additional sworn or civilian personnel if the funding for the personnel is provided in the ordinance of estimates or any other source; and applying the Act to all full-time sworn law enforcement officers who are deputy sheriffs at the rank of lieutenant or below and court security officers.
bill_summary: The bill increases the number of assistant sheriffs that must be appointed by the Baltimore City Sheriff, authorizes the Sheriff to appoint additional staff, and establishes procedures for collective bargaining and staffing in the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Sheriff’s Office and the Baltimore City government
stakeholders: Employees of the Baltimore City Sheriff’s Office, including sworn law enforcement officers and civilian staff, and the residents of Baltimore City who are served by the Sheriff's Office.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on staffing and collective bargaining procedures for the Baltimore City Sheriff’s Office and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services to identify reentry services in the State, develop a plan to establish a new division within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and develop a plan to expand certain services for individuals after release from incarceration; and requiring the Task Force to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Task Force to create a Division of Returning Citizens and expand reentry services for formerly incarcerated individuals in Maryland. It aims to assess current services, identify gaps, and develop plans to improve housing, employment, health, legal, and educational support for returning citizens.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Formerly incarcerated individuals and their families, reentry organizations, community programs, and the general public in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but by improving reentry services, it may indirectly support economic stability for returning citizens, which can benefit local economies.

Title: State Agency Workforce Policy for the 21st Century Act
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that an appointing authority send a copy of the selection plan and job announcement to the Secretary of Budget and Management at least 1 week before posting a job announcement; and repealing the requirement that the appointing authority wait until after the close of a position announcement to review qualified applicants.
bill_summary: The bill promotes fair employment practices by prohibiting the use of educational attainment as a barrier in hiring and advancement within Maryland state government, and it updates classification and recruitment procedures to improve efficiency and transparency.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Budget and Management and the Secretary of Budget and Management.
stakeholders: State government employees and applicants for Maryland state government jobs.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions primarily focus on state employment practices and do not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Consumer Protection – Self–Administered Sexual Assault Evidence Collection Kits
Synopsis: Providing that a party in a criminal trial involving an allegation of sexually assaultive behavior may not introduce information that physical evidence of sexually assaultive behavior was obtained using certain materials; providing that selling, offering for sale, or distributing a certain self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kit is an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice; establishing the Forensic Nurse Examiner Training Grant Program and the Forensic Nurse Examiner Training Grant Program Fund; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits the sale, offer for sale, or distribution of self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kits, establishes a grant program to fund training for forensic nurse examiners, and sets rules for evidence admissibility and rights related to sexual assault evidence collection in Maryland.
responsible_party: The Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services and the Attorney General's Office.
stakeholders: Victims of sexual assault, forensic nurse examiners, nonprofit organizations providing resources for sexual assault victims, and individuals who may use self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kits.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's impact on small business failure rates is minimal, as it mainly involves regulatory and enforcement provisions rather than direct support or economic incentives for small businesses.

Title: Behavioral Health Advisory Council and Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the membership and terms of members of the Behavioral Health Advisory Council; altering the membership of the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access; and requiring the Commission, in coordination with the Council, to make recommendations regarding the continuation of the State's behavioral health carve-out and the financing structure and quality oversight necessary to integrate somatic and behavioral health services and ensure compliance with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act.
bill_summary: The bill establishes and modifies the structure, membership, and responsibilities of the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access in Maryland. It aims to improve behavioral health services, assess needs, make policy recommendations, and ensure integration with somatic health services, including compliance with federal parity laws.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Behavioral Health Advisory Council
stakeholders: Individuals with behavioral health disorders, their families, behavioral health providers, and state agencies involved in health and social services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on improving behavioral health services and infrastructure may indirectly support small behavioral health providers by identifying needs and best practices, but it does not explicitly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Maternal Health – Assessments, Referrals, and Reporting (Maryland Maternal Health Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing requirements on local health departments and certain health care providers and facilities regarding maternal health, including requirements regarding prenatal risk assessment forms and postpartum infant and maternal referral forms; requiring hospitals and freestanding birthing centers to participate in the Severe Maternal Morbidity Surveillance Program to identify risk factors and causes of Severe Maternal Morbidity; requiring the Program to report its findings and recommendations by December 1, 2025;  etc.
bill_summary: The Maryland Maternal Health Act of 2024 establishes new requirements for local health departments and healthcare providers regarding maternal health assessments, referrals, and reporting. It includes the development of a report card for birthing facilities, mandates postpartum follow-up, and studies severe maternal morbidity to improve maternal health outcomes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health in collaboration with the Maryland Health Care Commission and local health departments.
stakeholders: Pregnant women, postpartum mothers, newborns, healthcare providers, hospitals, and birthing centers in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve maternal health outcomes and quality of care, which can contribute to reducing failures in small healthcare businesses such as birthing centers and hospitals by promoting best practices and quality improvement.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - 46th Alcoholic Beverages District - Revisions
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a total of 10 new Class B-D-7 licenses and a total of 2 new Class A-7 licenses within a certain bounded area; providing that, in the 46th alcoholic beverages district in Baltimore City, a certain license may be issued and an existing license may be moved to a building that is within 300 feet of a place of worship or school under certain circumstances; prohibiting the Board from authorizing a license to a recipient of a certain State grant; etc.
bill_summary: The bill revises regulations for alcoholic beverages licenses in Baltimore City's 46th district, including issuing new licenses, license transfers, conversions, and restrictions near places of worship or schools, as well as extending license expiration dates for certain transfers.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders, businesses operating in Baltimore City's 46th district, local community members, and places of worship or schools in the district.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides flexibility in licensing, transfer extensions, and operational hours, which can help small businesses adapt and reduce the risk of failure.

Title: State Board of Nursing - Executive Director Qualifications
Synopsis: Altering the qualifications for the executive director of the State Board of Nursing.
bill_summary: The bill studies and considers changing the qualifications for the executive director of the Maryland State Board of Nursing, including examining qualifications of similar roles in other states and other health boards, and requires a report on findings and recommendations by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Nursing professionals, healthcare regulatory agencies, and the public served by the State Board of Nursing
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure, but the study and potential changes could impact the administrative and operational environment of the Board, indirectly affecting small healthcare providers.

Title: State Board of Pharmacy - Prohibition on Discrimination Against 340B Drug Distribution
Synopsis: Prohibiting a 340B manufacturer from taking certain direct or indirect  actions to limit or restrict the acquisition or delivery of a 340B drug; making a violation of the Act an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice within the meaning of the Consumer Protection Act; and requiring the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board to conduct a study of the 340B Program and report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly by July 1, 2026.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits certain actions by 340B drug manufacturers and related entities that limit or restrict the distribution of 340B drugs, makes violations an unfair trade practice, and requires a study on the 340B program's implementation and impact in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Covered entities, 340B drug manufacturers, pharmacies, and patients benefiting from the 340B program in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to prevent unfair restrictions and practices that could harm small businesses involved in the distribution of 340B drugs, potentially reducing their risk of failure.

Title: Carroll County – Sheriff – Salary
Synopsis: Increasing the annual salary of the Sheriff of Carroll County to $191,078.10 beginning in 2026 and $212,309 beginning in 2027.
bill_summary: The bill increases the salary of the Sheriff of Carroll County to match the salary of a Department of State Police Lieutenant Colonel starting in 2026, with adjustments every four years based on the State Police pay plan, and sets specific salary amounts for 2023 and 2027.
responsible_party: Carroll County Government and the Maryland Department of State Police
stakeholders: The Sheriff of Carroll County and residents of Carroll County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to sheriff salary adjustments.

Title: Criminal Organizations - Underlying Crime
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "underlying crime" that is applicable to certain prohibitions against participation in criminal organizations.
bill_summary: The bill establishes civil and criminal procedures to combat criminal organizations, including civil actions for damages, injunctions, and forfeiture of property connected to criminal activities, and sets statutes of limitations for these actions.
responsible_party: Maryland State's Attorney's Office and law enforcement agencies involved in investigation and prosecution of criminal organizations.
stakeholders: Individuals and entities involved in or affected by criminal organizations, including victims, property owners, and the general public.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes provisions for the forfeiture of property used in criminal activities, with specific procedures to protect innocent owners, which could help reduce the failure of legitimate small businesses that might otherwise be unfairly targeted or affected.

Title: Income Tax Subtraction Modification – Death Benefits – Law Enforcement Officers and Fire Fighters
Synopsis: Allowing a subtraction under the Maryland income tax for the payment of a death benefit under a collective bargaining agreement to a spouse or beneficiary of a law enforcement officer or fire fighter whose death arises out of the course of employment; and applying the Act retroactively to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2021.
bill_summary: The bill allows a Maryland income tax subtraction for death benefits paid to the surviving spouse or beneficiary of a deceased law enforcement officer or firefighter, under certain circumstances, and applies retroactively to tax years beginning after December 31, 2021.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Revenue
stakeholders: Law enforcement officers, firefighters, their families, and beneficiaries in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to individual death benefits and tax adjustments.

Title: Public Safety - Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program to assist community organizations, nonprofit entities, and local governments in funding security operations during times of high pedestrian traffic in certain entertainment districts; establishing the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program Fund; authorizing the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2026 and each fiscal year thereafter, to include up to $1,000,000 in the annual budget bill for the Fund; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program to fund security operations in entertainment districts with high pedestrian traffic and reported crime. It creates a dedicated fund, sets eligibility criteria, and authorizes annual appropriations to support community and local government security efforts.
responsible_party: The Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Community organizations, nonprofit entities, local governments, and residents in Maryland entertainment districts
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program aims to improve safety in entertainment districts, which can help local businesses by reducing crime-related issues and encouraging more patronage, thereby potentially decreasing business failure rates.

Title: Income Tax - Opportunity for Filers to Register to Make Anatomical Gift
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller to implement procedures to offer certain income tax return filers the opportunity to register to make an anatomical gift in accordance with the Maryland Revised Uniform Anatomical Gift Act through a hyperlink to the anatomical gift donor registry.
bill_summary: The bill allows Maryland income tax filers to register as organ donors when they file their taxes by indicating their consent on their tax return. The Comptroller will include a checkoff on the tax form and cooperate with the organ registry to transfer donor information.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office and the State's designated organ registry organization
stakeholders: Taxpayers filing income tax returns in Maryland, and individuals in need of organ transplants
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates, as it primarily involves tax filing procedures and organ donor registration.

Title: Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing to study and make recommendations regarding certain services, programs, advocacy, outreach efforts, and other items to improve the quality of life of individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by June 1, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Workgroup and a Commission for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing in Maryland to study, assess, and make recommendations on services, programs, and policies to improve accessibility, inclusion, and quality of life for these communities.
responsible_party: The Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing and the Maryland State government agencies involved in implementing the recommendations and programs.
stakeholders: Individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing in Maryland, including their families and community organizations.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it may indirectly support businesses by improving accessibility and community engagement.

Title: Health Insurance - Mental Health and Substance Use Disorder Benefits - Sunset Repeal and Modification of Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Altering certain reporting requirements on health insurance carriers relating to compliance with the federal Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act; altering requirements for certain analyses of nonquantitative treatment limitations required of health insurance carriers; establishing certain remedies the Commissioner may use to enforce compliance with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act and related reporting requirements; repealing the requirement that a certain form be used for the reporting requirements; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies reporting requirements for health insurance carriers to ensure compliance with the federal Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act, including analyses of nonquantitative treatment limitations and enforcement remedies.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, mental health and substance use disorder beneficiaries in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve compliance and transparency in mental health coverage, which could reduce small business failures related to mental health coverage issues.

Title: Education - Blind and Visually Impaired Students - Textbook Equity
Synopsis: Establishing requirements for each county board of education regarding provision of the instructional materials that will be used in the upcoming school year for students with individualized education programs; requiring the county board to coordinate with the Instructional Resources Center to provide the materials in a specialized format to blind or visually impaired students; requiring, beginning January 1, 2025, certain textbook publishers to provide an electronic file of pupil edition textbooks; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes requirements for Maryland county school boards to ensure that instructional materials for blind and visually impaired students are provided in specialized formats such as braille, large print, audio, or digital text. It mandates coordination with the Instructional Resources Center and publishers to facilitate timely access to these materials, including provisions for funding and reporting on progress and accessibility.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education and the Instructional Resources Center
stakeholders: Blind and visually impaired students in Maryland schools
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill encourages publishers to provide electronic files of textbooks in NIMAS format and to produce specialized formats, which could support small publishers and educational material providers by creating a market for accessible educational materials.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Remote Ultrasound Procedures and Remote Fetal Nonstress Tests
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide remote ultrasound procedures and remote fetal nonstress tests if the patient is in a residence or a location other than the office of the patient's provider and the provider follows the same standard of care that the provider would follow when providing the services on-site.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide remote ultrasound procedures and remote fetal nonstress tests for eligible pregnant women, especially when services are provided outside of a healthcare provider’s office, ensuring standard of care and secure digital technology use.
responsible_party: Maryland Medical Assistance Program (administered by the Maryland Department of Health)
stakeholders: Pregnant women eligible for Medicaid in Maryland, healthcare providers offering prenatal care, and remote healthcare technology providers.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts healthcare providers and technology providers by establishing standards and reimbursement for remote prenatal testing, which could help reduce small business failure by expanding service offerings and reimbursement.

Title: Public Safety - Automatic License Plate Readers - Captured Plate Data Storage and Upload
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "historical data" to include automatic license plate reader data stored by cloud computing; establishing that certain captured automatic license plate reader data is the property of a certain law enforcement agency and may not be sold for any purpose; establishing that certain captured automatic license plate reader data may be uploaded to the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center; and extending certain penalties for a violation of the Act to a vendor contracted by a law enforcement agency.
bill_summary: The bill modifies regulations around automatic license plate reader data, establishing that certain data is property of law enforcement, cannot be sold, and can only be uploaded to the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center. It also extends certain offenses to vendors and requires procedures for data use and security.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police and law enforcement agencies using automatic license plate reader systems
stakeholders: Law enforcement agencies and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on data management and security for law enforcement, with no direct provisions affecting small business failure rates.

Title: Blueprint for Maryland's Future Implementation - Funding for Implementation Coordinators
Synopsis: Requiring for each fiscal year each county board of education to provide $150,000 for the salary and benefits of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future implementation coordinator in the county; and requiring the implementation coordinator's salary and benefits to be paid for by the State and the county in a certain proportion.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that each Maryland county board of education funds the salary and benefits of a Blueprint implementation coordinator, with costs shared between the state and the county. It also requires the contracting of independent evaluations of the Blueprint's implementation and progress reports to the Governor and General Assembly, including assessments of student achievement, funding use, and goal achievement.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and local county boards of education
stakeholders: Students, teachers, and families in Maryland public schools
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it involves funding and program implementation that could indirectly impact local economies.

Title: Alcoholic Beverages - Class 4 Limited Winery License - Requirements and Authorizations
Synopsis: Altering certain cultivation or production requirements applicable to a holder of a Class 4 limited winery license by basing them on certain agricultural products instead of grapes and other fruit; and altering the standards for the purchase of certain wine by a license holder.
bill_summary: The bill modifies requirements for the Class 4 limited winery license in Maryland, allowing the use of Maryland-grown agricultural products other than grapes and fruit for wine production, and updates standards for purchasing and blending wine. It also clarifies licensing, production, and sales regulations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture and the Alcoholic Beverages Administration
stakeholders: Winemakers, small wineries, and consumers of Maryland wine products
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By easing cultivation and production requirements and clarifying licensing rules, the bill aims to support small wineries and reduce their risk of failure.

Title: Compensation for Individuals Erroneously Convicted - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain benefits that a certain individual who has been erroneously convicted of a crime is entitled to receive; requiring the State to notify a certain individual of certain information in writing under certain circumstances when the State intends to reduce or prevent an award of compensation to the individual; and repealing obsolete provisions of law relating to the filing of a certain petition for compensation.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the benefits and compensation process for individuals who have been erroneously convicted of a crime in Maryland, including changes to eligibility, notification requirements, and the scope of benefits provided.
responsible_party: The Board of Public Works and the Office of Administrative Hearings in Maryland.
stakeholders: Individuals who have been erroneously convicted and their estates.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it involves state agencies and legal processes that could indirectly impact economic stability.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Class B Beer, Wine, and Liquor Licenses
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a Class B beer, wine, and liquor license in a certain area; and establishing the requirements for a holder of the license.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Baltimore City to issue a new type of Class B alcohol license for restaurants in specific downtown districts, with certain requirements such as food sales constituting at least 51% of daily receipts, and limits the license to be issued before June 30, 2028.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Restaurants and food service businesses in Baltimore City's Downtown Management District, Ward 4, Precincts 1 and 2
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill could help small restaurants by providing a new license option, potentially increasing their revenue and stability, but it does not directly target small business failure reduction.

Title: 9-1-1 Trust Fund - Purposes - Training in Telecommunications Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation
Synopsis: Altering the purposes of the 9-1-1 Trust Fund to including funding the costs of telecommunications cardiopulmonary resuscitation training.
bill_summary: The bill updates the purposes of the Maryland 9-1-1 Trust Fund to include funding for telecommunications cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) training for public safety answering point personnel, establishes training standards for this CPR, and specifies the content of the training.
responsible_party: Maryland 9-1-1 Board
stakeholders: Public safety answering point personnel and emergency dispatchers in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Anne Arundel County - Human Relations Commission - Subpoena Enforcement
Synopsis: Authorizing the Human Relations Commission of Anne Arundel County to apply to a circuit court in any county to seek relief if a party fails to comply with a subpoena.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission to seek court enforcement if a party fails to comply with a subpoena, including applying for court orders and issuing body attachments to compel compliance.
responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission and the Circuit Court of Anne Arundel County
stakeholders: Individuals and organizations subject to subpoenas issued by the Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to subpoena enforcement for the Human Relations Commission.

Title: State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners - Veterinary Technicians and Veterinary Assistants
Synopsis: Authorizing a veterinary assistant to perform certain tasks under the immediate or direct supervision of a veterinary practitioner or a veterinary technician under the direct supervision of a veterinary practitioner; and authorizing a veterinary technician to perform certain procedures, including certain emergency procedures and euthanasia, if the veterinary practitioner determines the veterinary technician is qualified to perform the procedures.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes veterinary assistants to perform certain tasks under supervision, expands the roles of veterinary technicians, and establishes an alternative pathway for employed veterinary assistants to become licensed veterinary technicians by a certain date.
responsible_party: The State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners
stakeholders: Veterinary assistants, veterinary technicians, veterinarians, and animal patients in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill could help small veterinary practices by expanding the roles of staff and creating pathways for assistants to become licensed technicians, potentially improving efficiency and reducing failure rates.

Title: Standing - Environmental and Natural Resources Protection Proceedings (Clean Water Justice Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Providing certain persons standing in environmental and natural resources protection proceedings; authorizing persons that meet standing requirements to bring certain civil actions under certain circumstances; requiring a plaintiff, under certain circumstances, to give certain notice and provide certain documentation to the Department of the Environment and the Attorney General and to file a certain affidavit; authorizing a court to grant certain relief, award certain costs, and impose certain civil penalties; etc.
bill_summary: The Clean Water Justice Act of 2024 expands standing rights for individuals, associations, and other entities to participate in environmental and water resource protection proceedings, including civil actions, to address violations and protect water quality in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and the Attorney General's Office
stakeholders: Individuals, environmental groups, water resource users, and communities affected by water pollution and resource violations in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides legal avenues for environmental enforcement, which could help prevent small business failures related to environmental violations by clarifying legal standing and procedures.

Title: Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program in the Maryland Department of Aging; establishing that the purpose and the goals of the Pilot Program are to support the "village" concept of local, volunteer-led organizations that aim to provide certain services to community members who choose to age in place and to expand those services to more residents in the geographic region; and requiring the Montgomery County Village Consortium to establish a certain plan and submit certain reports.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program in Maryland to support social connections and aging in place for seniors through a hub and spoke model, managed by the Department of Aging and implemented by the Montgomery County Village Consortium.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
stakeholders: Senior citizens aging in place and local volunteer-led organizations supporting them in Montgomery County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program aims to improve social support and resource coordination for seniors, which may indirectly support small businesses involved in community services, but it does not directly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Advanced Practice Registered Nurses - Certification Requirement and Exceptions
Synopsis: Requiring an individual, subject to certain exceptions, to be certified as an advanced practice registered nurse before practicing advanced practice registered nursing in the State.
bill_summary: The bill requires individuals to be certified as advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) before practicing in Maryland, with certain exceptions such as students, federal employees, and emergency responders. It updates licensing and certification requirements for APRNs.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Nursing
stakeholders: Advanced practice registered nurses, nursing students, healthcare facilities, and patients in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on certification requirements for nurses and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact - City of Frederick
Synopsis: Authorizing the City of Frederick to participate in the Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the City of Frederick to participate in the Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact, which facilitates mutual emergency assistance and cooperation among jurisdictions in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Emergency Management
stakeholders: Jurisdictions within Maryland, including the City of Frederick, and their residents, especially during emergencies and disaster response activities.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on emergency management cooperation.

Title: County Boards of Education – Budgets – Notice (Transparency in Education Spending Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Education to adopt a process for the uniform and timely reporting of certain county board of education budget information to a county governing body; requiring a county board to post certain budget information on the county board's public-facing website, in an easily identifiable location; requiring a certain audit to be sent to the county council or the county commissioners; etc.
bill_summary: The bill mandates the Maryland State Board of Education to establish a standardized process for the timely and uniform reporting of county school district budgets to local governing bodies. It requires county school boards to post budget information on their websites, limits certain transfers without approval, and enhances transparency through audits and public reports.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Education and county school boards
stakeholders: County school districts, local government officials, and the general public interested in education funding and transparency
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on education budget transparency and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Business Regulation - Restaurants and Traders - Licensing Requirements
Synopsis: Altering an exception for licensed restaurants to the requirement that a person who does business as a trader or an exhibitor have a trader's license to apply only to restaurants that generate 10% or less of their annual sales from nonfood items.
bill_summary: The bill amends licensing requirements for traders and exhibitors in Maryland, specifically altering an exception for restaurants. It now exempts restaurants that generate 10% or less of their annual sales from nonfood items from needing a trader's license.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Business Regulation
stakeholders: Restaurants in Maryland, especially those with a small percentage of nonfood sales
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By reducing licensing burdens for certain restaurants, the bill aims to lower operational barriers, potentially decreasing the failure rate among small restaurants.

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Failure to Repair Serious and Dangerous Defects - Tenant Remedies (Tenant Safety Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing that a landlord that offers a residential dwelling unit for rent is deemed to warrant the dwelling fit for human habitation; authorizing multiple tenants to join as plaintiffs in a civil action against a landlord and authorizing a court to issue an order for separate trials or other orders necessary to prevent delay or avoid prejudice; providing that a court may order certain relief in civil actions relating to the breach of warranty of habitability, including actual damages, abatement of rent, and lease termination; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes that landlords in Maryland are deemed to warrant that rental dwellings are fit for human habitation, especially concerning serious and dangerous defects such as mold, and provides tenants with legal remedies, including rent abatement and repair orders, if landlords fail to repair hazardous conditions.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development and courts
stakeholders: Tenants living in residential rental units in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts landlords and tenants by providing clear legal remedies for hazardous conditions, which could reduce disputes and legal failures related to property conditions, but it does not directly target small business failure.

Title: Harford County – Alcoholic Beverages – Performing Arts Theater License
Synopsis: Altering eligibility for a performing arts theater license in Harford County by altering the definition of "performing arts theater" and authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Harford County to issue the license to a certain for-profit theater, rather than a nonprofit theater; authorizing the holder of the license to sell liquor for on-premises consumption in addition to beer and wine; and altering the license fee from $500 to $1,500.
bill_summary: The bill allows Harford County to issue a performing arts theater license to for-profit theaters, expanding eligibility beyond nonprofit theaters. It permits license holders to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption during performances, intermissions, and receptions, with an increased annual fee of $1,500.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Harford County
stakeholders: Performing arts theaters, theater audiences, and local residents in Harford County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By enabling for-profit theaters to obtain alcohol licenses and sell liquor, the bill may support the financial stability of theaters, potentially reducing small business failure.

Title: Maryland Health Care Commission – Nursing Homes – Acquisitions
Synopsis: Requiring a person, at least 60 days before the closing date of the acquisition of a nursing home, to submit a request for acquisition to the Maryland Health Care Commission and provide certain notice to residents, resident representatives, and employees of the nursing home; establishing requirements regarding the approval or denial of a request for acquisition of a nursing home; providing for judicial review of a final decision of the Commission regarding a request for acquisition of a nursing home; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires a person to submit a request for approval to acquire a nursing home to the Maryland Health Care Commission before closing on the acquisition. It establishes procedures for review, approval, or denial of the request, and mandates reporting and regulatory standards post-acquisition to ensure quality and proper management of nursing homes.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission
stakeholders: Nursing home residents, staff, owners, and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for review and regulation aim to ensure stable management and quality standards, which could reduce the risk of small business failure in the nursing home sector.

Title: Certified Nursing Assistants - Licensing Requirements and Administrative Updates
Synopsis: Exempting an individual who practices as a certain nursing assistant for less than 4 months under federal regulations from the State's certification requirement; altering the designation of, and licensure requirements for, certified nursing assistants and geriatric nursing assistants; requiring an applicant for certification as a certified nursing assistant to complete a nursing assistant competency evaluation; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates licensing requirements for certified nursing assistants (CNAs) in Maryland, including exemptions for short-term practice, new categories of CNAs, and requirements for competency evaluations. It also establishes training program standards and updates certification procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Nursing and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Certified nursing assistants, nursing homes, healthcare facilities, and residents in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for training and certification aim to streamline CNA licensing, potentially reducing barriers for small healthcare providers and improving workforce stability, which can help decrease small business failure.

Title: Sexual Assault Forensic Examinations Conducted Through Telehealth - Reimbursement and Study
Synopsis: Authorizing the reimbursement of a sexual assault forensic exam conducted through peer-to-peer telehealth under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee to conduct a study on the feasibility of a telehealth program that includes a pilot program for conducting sexual assault forensic examinations through telehealth; and requiring the Committee to report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes reimbursement for sexual assault forensic examinations conducted via peer-to-peer telehealth and mandates a study on the feasibility of implementing a telehealth program, including a pilot program, for sexual assault examinations in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee
stakeholders: Victims of sexual assault and child sexual abuse in Maryland, healthcare providers, hospitals, and forensic examiners.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it encourages hospitals and healthcare providers to seek funding for telehealth programs, which could indirectly support healthcare infrastructure.

Title: Labor and Employment – Workforce Development – Talent Innovation Program and Fund
Synopsis: Establishing the Talent Innovation Program in the Maryland Department of Labor to increase access to high-quality job training by using innovative and sustainable talent financing mechanisms to help meet skill needs in the State's prominent and emerging industry sectors; and requiring the Department, beginning on January 1, 2025, and each January 1 thereafter, to report to the Governor, the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House on Program activities and use of the Talent Innovation Fund.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Talent Innovation Program and Fund within the Maryland Department of Labor to enhance access to high-quality job training in key industries such as cybersecurity, healthcare, biotechnology, manufacturing, and artificial intelligence.
