responsible_party: Interagency Commission on School Construction and Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Public school students, school staff, and local education agencies in Maryland, especially in Prince George's County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes provisions for funding and project prioritization that could streamline school construction processes, potentially reducing delays and failures in small business participation in school projects.

Title: Electric System Planning - Scope and Funding
Synopsis: Altering the scope of certain policy goals with regard to energy systems; requiring the Public Service Commission to report on certain projects relating to certain goals; altering the scope of certain funds that may be used for certain projects; requiring the Commission to adopt regulations to require investment in certain demand-side reliability and efficiency improvement methods; requiring that certain regulations adopted and orders issued by the Commission by December 31, 2025, be developed in a certain manner; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland's electric system planning policies to focus on reducing greenhouse gases, increasing renewable energy, improving system resiliency, and promoting energy efficiency. It requires the Public Service Commission to report on progress, encourages pursuit of federal funds for system upgrades, and mandates regulations to support demand-side improvements and fair labor standards for federally funded projects.
responsible_party: Public Service Commission of Maryland and Maryland Energy Administration
stakeholders: Electric utilities, renewable energy developers, vulnerable communities, and consumers in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill promotes federal funding and fair labor standards for electric system projects, which can support small business participation and reduce project failures.

Title: Civil Rights - Discrimination Based on Protected Characteristics and Reproductive Freedom
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions of law prohibiting discrimination based on certain protected characteristics to include prohibitions on discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity, race, religious beliefs, marital status, and disability; and withdrawing and repealing Chapter 244 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 2023.
bill_summary: The bill broadens Maryland's anti-discrimination laws to explicitly include protections based on sexual orientation, gender identity, race, religious beliefs, marital status, and disability across various sectors such as employment, housing, education, health care, and public utilities. It repeals a previous chapter related to discrimination and establishes comprehensive prohibitions against discrimination based on these protected characteristics.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies and departments responsible for enforcing anti-discrimination laws, including the Maryland Department of Labor, Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, Maryland State Department of Education, Maryland Department of Health, and other relevant regulatory bodies.
stakeholders: Individuals and groups protected under the law, including employees, students, consumers, residents, and vendors, particularly those belonging to or identified by the protected categories such as sexual orientation, gender identity, race, religion, disability, and marital status.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions aim to create a more equitable environment by prohibiting discrimination in business practices, which can help small businesses by fostering a fair marketplace and reducing legal risks associated with discriminatory practices.

Title: Montgomery County – State’s Attorney’s Office Personnel – Application of County Personnel Laws and Collective Bargaining MC 12–24
Synopsis: Establishing the right of certain employees of the Office of the State's Attorney in Montgomery County to organize and collectively bargain in accordance with certain personnel law governing county employees; establishing that employees of the Office of the State's Attorney are subject to the county merit system law and personnel regulations; establishing certain requirements related to collective bargaining for employees of the Office; etc.
bill_summary: The bill allows employees of the Montgomery County State’s Attorney’s Office to organize and collectively bargain over employment terms, with the County Executive and the State’s Attorney designated as the respective employers for different bargaining topics. It aligns these employees under the county personnel laws and establishes procedures for collective bargaining, including the creation of a single master agreement.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Government and the Montgomery County State’s Attorney’s Office
stakeholders: Employees of the Montgomery County State’s Attorney’s Office, including non-supervisory assistant state’s attorneys, and the Montgomery County government
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates; it focuses on employment and collective bargaining procedures within a government office.

Title: Dorchester County - Definition of Public School Employee - Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "public school employee" to include supervisory noncertificated employees in Dorchester County for purposes of collective bargaining.
bill_summary: The bill amends the definition of 'public school employee' in Dorchester County to include supervisory noncertificated employees for collective bargaining purposes.
responsible_party: Dorchester County Public Schools or the Dorchester County Board of Education
stakeholders: Supervisory noncertificated employees in Dorchester County public schools
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to public school employment classifications.

Title: Education - Blueprint for Maryland's Future - Alterations
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Department of Education to award funding for a new Judy Center or Family Support Center for planning and development under a certain circumstance; requiring the State Board to approve certain specifications for teachers and administrators relating to time spent in the classroom and time spent on other teacher activities; altering certain requirements relating to student-to-classroom personnel ratios and funding timelines for the Prekindergarten Expansion Grant Program; etc.
bill_summary: The bill makes various alterations to Maryland's education policies, including funding for new Judy Centers, changes to teacher certification and professional development programs, expansion of prekindergarten programs, and updates to evaluation and reporting requirements for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Department of Education and the Maryland State Board of Education.
stakeholders: Students, teachers, early childhood educators, parents, and local school systems in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on education policy and program funding, with no direct provisions targeting small business failure reduction.

Title: Emergency Services - Funding
Synopsis: Increasing the motor vehicle registration emergency medical system surcharge for certain motor vehicles; providing for the distribution of revenues derived from the surcharge; altering certain provisions of law related to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund; increasing the fines for certain violations related to driving while impaired; requiring the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2026, to include an annual appropriation to the Senator William H. Amoss Fire, Rescue, and Ambulance Fund of at least $16,500,000; etc.
bill_summary: The bill increases funding for trauma centers and emergency medical services in Maryland by raising surcharges on motor vehicle registrations and fines, and allocates these funds to various trauma and emergency response programs, including trauma physician support, trauma center grants, and emergency medical system operations.
responsible_party: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems and the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Trauma patients, trauma physicians, trauma centers, emergency medical services, and Maryland residents requiring emergency care.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides financial support to trauma physicians and centers, which may help reduce the financial strain on small trauma-related healthcare providers, potentially decreasing their failure rate.

Title: Howard County Public Schools - Differences in Capital Budget Proposals - Report Ho. Co. 16-24
Synopsis: Requiring the Howard County Board of Education, under certain circumstances, to publish on the website of the Howard County public school system a report that details the differences between the Howard County Superintendent of Schools' proposed capital budget and the capital budget approved by the Howard County Board of Education and the detailed rationale for each difference; requiring the Howard County Board of Education to submit the report to the General Assembly; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Howard County Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools to publish reports on their websites and submit them to the General Assembly when there are differences between proposed and approved capital budgets or capital improvement programs.
responsible_party: Howard County Board of Education and Howard County Superintendent of Schools
stakeholders: Howard County public school students, staff, and community members
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Early Childhood Education - Publicly Funded Prekindergarten Programs - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering staff qualifications in eligible prekindergarten programs; authorizing a county board to apply for funding to lease space for  prekindergarten programs; establishing an early childhood educator career ladder; requiring the Department of Education to establish prekindergarten provider hubs; requiring the Department to distribute a list of eligible private prekindergarten providers; requiring the Governor to appropriate in fiscal year 2026 an amount that is at least equal to the amount appropriated in fiscal year 2024; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates and expands Maryland's early childhood education programs, including requirements for teacher qualifications, increasing private provider slots, establishing a career ladder for educators, creating provider hubs, and improving program quality and access.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and local county boards of education.
stakeholders: Prekindergarten children, families, private and public early childhood education providers, and educators in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides support and resources for private prekindergarten providers, including publicizing provider lists and offering technical assistance, which may help reduce small business failure rates.

Title: Howard County Task Force to Study Revenue Options for School Capital Needs Ho. Co. 18-24
Synopsis: Establishing the Howard County Task Force to Study Revenue Options for School Capital Needs to identify capital needs of Howard County Public Schools and study options for closing any identified funding gaps; requiring the Howard County Council to submit a resolution to the Howard County Delegation to the General Assembly if the county council makes a certain determination; and requiring the Task Force to report its findings and recommendations to the Howard County members of the House of Delegates and the Senate by October 31, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Howard County Task Force to study revenue options for funding the capital needs of Howard County Public Schools, including identifying funding gaps and recommending potential revenue sources.
responsible_party: Howard County Department of Finance and Howard County Budget Office, with oversight and staffing provided by the Howard County Executive and County Council.
stakeholders: Howard County Public Schools, students, parents, teachers, and residents of Howard County.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, as it focuses on funding for public school infrastructure.

Title: Arts Incubator Workgroup - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Arts Incubator Workgroup to study how arts and cultural institutions can support local artists; requiring the Workgroup to submit to the Governor and the General Assembly by January 1, 2025, a preliminary report on its findings, including research, case studies, and examples of approaches used to support artists in other areas; and requiring the Workgroup to submit a final report by October 1, 2025, with recommendations on any necessary budget, facilities, or in-kind services to support local artists.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Arts Incubator Workgroup to study how arts and cultural institutions can support local artists, and requires the group to submit preliminary and final reports with recommendations and potential support strategies.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Arts Council and the Governor's Office
stakeholders: Local artists, arts and cultural institutions, arts councils, arts districts, and the general public supporting the arts in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to support local artists and arts organizations, which could help improve their sustainability and reduce failure rates.

Title: Soil Conservation Districts - Small Ponds - Plan Review Fees
Synopsis: Authorizing a soil conservation district to recommend a fee system to cover the cost of reviewing plans for small ponds; establishing that any fees collected under the Act shall be supplemental to county and State funds; requiring a soil conservation district, in developing a fee system for small pond plans, to determine for the succeeding year the reasonable cost of reviewing the plans; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes soil conservation districts to recommend a fee system to cover the costs of reviewing plans for small ponds that are exempt from permit requirements, and establishes procedures for implementing these fees.
responsible_party: Soil Conservation Districts and the local governing body of Maryland
stakeholders: Landowners and land occupiers with small ponds in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill could help small pond owners by potentially reducing costs associated with plan review, which may support small business or individual landowners involved in pond construction or maintenance.

Title: Professional and Volunteer Firefighter Innovative Cancer Screening Technologies Program - Funding
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2025, to include at least $500,000 in the annual budget for the Professional and Volunteer Firefighter Innovative Cancer Screening Technologies Program.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Governor to allocate funds annually to the Professional and Volunteer Firefighter Innovative Cancer Screening Technologies Program from fiscal year 2021 through 2024, with increased funding starting in 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland State Government, specifically the Office of the Governor and the Department of Health
stakeholders: Professional and volunteer firefighters in Maryland, and potentially the broader community benefiting from improved cancer screening technologies
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it could indirectly support small businesses involved in healthcare or technology related to cancer screening.

Title: State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists - Appointment of Members
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to appoint the licensed audiologist members to the State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists from a list submitted by the Maryland Academy of Audiology rather than by the Board.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Governor to appoint licensed audiologist members to the State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech–Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists from a list submitted by the Maryland Academy of Audiology, rather than directly by the Board.
responsible_party: Governor of Maryland and the Maryland State Department of Health
stakeholders: Licensed audiologists, hearing aid dispensers, speech-language pathologists, music therapists, and the general public receiving their services
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill streamlines the appointment process for audiologist members, potentially reducing administrative delays and improving the efficiency of the licensing board, which may help small audiology practices.

Title: Uninsured Driving Penalties - Funding for the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund, Driver Education, and Transportation to Field Trips
Synopsis: Altering the penalty for failing to maintain certain required security for certain motor vehicles and the distribution of the revenue derived from the penalties; establishing the Driver Education in Public High Schools Grant Program to provide grants to public high schools and nonprofit organizations to assist public schools in offering driver education courses; establishing the State-Aided Institutions Field Trip Grant Program to assist public schools in transporting students to field trips at State-aided educational institutions; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies penalties for failing to maintain required vehicle security, allocates revenue from these penalties to various funds including the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund, and establishes grant programs to support driver education in high schools and transportation for school field trips to state-aided institutions.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Education and the Maryland Department of Transportation.
stakeholders: High school students, public high schools, nonprofit organizations, and public school students participating in field trips.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's impact on small business failure rates is indirect, primarily through funding allocations and program support, with no direct measures targeting small business failure reduction.

Title: Maryland Entertainment Council - Alterations
Synopsis: Reestablishing the Maryland Entertainment Council to be the Maryland Entertainment Industry Council within the Department of Commerce to assess the State's existing assets, study certain existing State programs, agencies, and offices, and make recommendations on the development of a strategic plan for Maryland's future in the entertainment industry; and requiring the Council to submit an annual report by January 1 each year and a report of certain recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill reestablishes the Maryland Entertainment Industry Council within the Department of Commerce to study and make recommendations for developing Maryland's film, television, and entertainment industry, including assessing assets, infrastructure, and industry needs, and proposing strategic plans and incentives.
responsible_party: Department of Commerce, Maryland Entertainment Industry Council, and other relevant state agencies.
stakeholders: Film, television, and entertainment industry professionals, independent creators, and related businesses in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to support and grow the entertainment industry through strategic planning, incentives, and workforce development, which could help reduce small business failures in this sector.

Title: Education - Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery - Student Information
Synopsis: Requiring public schools in the State to notify students taking the ASVAB and parents or guardians of students taking the ASVAB of the option to prohibit the release of a student's ASVAB test scores to military recruiters; and repealing the requirement that certain schools provide certain notice to certain individuals regarding the release of student information and ASVAB test scores.
bill_summary: The bill requires Maryland public schools to notify students and parents about the option to prevent the release of student ASVAB scores and contact information to military recruiters, and clarifies procedures for opting out and later releasing information.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education and local public school districts
stakeholders: Students taking the ASVAB, their parents or guardians, and military recruiters
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it focuses on student information and military recruitment procedures.

Title: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners - Scope of Practice, Reinstatements, and Examinations by Health Care Providers
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "practice massage therapy" to include, subject to certain education and training requirements, instrument-assisted soft tissue manipulation techniques that enhance or imitate manual techniques; altering the circumstances under which the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners is required to reinstate a license or registration; and requiring the Board to require a licensee or an applicant to submit to an examination by a health care provider under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill updates the scope of practice for massage therapists, including certain techniques, revises reinstatement procedures for licenses, and requires examinations by healthcare providers under specific circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
stakeholders: Licensed massage therapists, massage therapy applicants, and consumers of massage therapy services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for license reinstatement and scope of practice updates aim to streamline licensing and ensure qualified practitioners, potentially reducing small business failures related to licensing issues.

Title: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners - Aiding or Abetting Unauthorized Practice - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from aiding or abetting the unauthorized practice of massage therapy; and providing penalties for a first violation of the Act of a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment not to exceed 1 year and for a subsequent offense, a fine of up to $20,000 per day or imprisonment not to exceed 5 years.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits aiding or abetting the unauthorized practice of massage therapy in Maryland, establishes penalties for violations, and clarifies enforcement procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
stakeholders: Massage therapists, massage therapy businesses, and the general public seeking massage services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By clarifying legal boundaries and penalties, the bill aims to reduce illegal practice, which can help legitimate massage businesses operate without unfair competition and legal risks.

Title: State Government - Office of Legislative Audits - Performance Audits
Synopsis: Altering the frequency of certain performance audits of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City to once every 6 years instead of 4 years, and the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County to at least once every 6 years instead of 3 years that are required to be conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits.
bill_summary: The bill changes the required frequency of performance audits for certain liquor licensing boards in Maryland from once every 3 years to once every 6 years.
responsible_party: Office of Legislative Audits
stakeholders: Liquor licensing boards in Baltimore City, Prince George's County, and the City of Annapolis
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By extending the audit frequency, the bill may reduce administrative burdens on small liquor license businesses, potentially allowing them to focus more on operations.

Title: Election Law - Campaign Finance Activities - State Treasurer
Synopsis: Prohibiting, during a regular session of the General Assembly, the State Treasurer and a person acting on behalf of the State Treasurer, as to a candidate for federal, State, or local office or certain campaign finance entities, from receiving a contribution, conducting a fund-raising event, soliciting a contribution, or depositing or using any contribution of money that was not deposited prior to the session.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits the Maryland State Treasurer and individuals acting on their behalf from participating in certain campaign finance activities during the regular session of the General Assembly, including receiving contributions, conducting fundraising events, soliciting contributions, or depositing campaign contributions.
responsible_party: Maryland State Treasurer and their designated representatives
stakeholders: The Maryland State Treasurer, political candidates, campaign finance entities, and the general public interested in campaign finance transparency
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, focusing instead on campaign finance activities of government officials.

Title: Transportation - Major Change in Bus Service - Publication on Website
Synopsis: Altering the information that the Maryland Transit Administration is required to publish on its website before holding a public hearing on a major service change to include certain demographic information, a summary of any publicly available minutes, records, or documents related to the service change, and a brief statement explaining the reason for the service change; and requiring the Administration to distribute the report to certain officials and entities, including each member of the General Assembly whose district would be impacted.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Transit Administration to compile and publish detailed reports on the impacts of proposed major bus service reductions or cancellations, including demographic and community effects, at least 30 days before public hearings. It also mandates conducting equity and cost-benefit analyses, community outreach, and transparency in the decision-making process.
responsible_party: Maryland Transit Administration and Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Bus riders, community members, local businesses, schools, and vulnerable populations such as disabled riders and low-income communities in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve transparency and community engagement in bus service changes, which can help mitigate negative impacts on local businesses and communities, potentially reducing small business failures related to transportation disruptions.

Title: Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup to study the regional water governance approach in the Baltimore region; requiring the Governor to include an appropriation of $500,000 in the annual budget bill for the Workgroup; and requiring the Workgroup to report, on or before June 30, 2027, its findings to the Mayor of Baltimore City, the County Executive of Baltimore County, the Governor, and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup to study and analyze the potential implementation of a regional water governance approach in the Baltimore area, including legal, financial, operational, and equity considerations, and to report findings by June 30, 2027.
responsible_party: Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup, jointly designated by the Mayor of Baltimore City and the County Executive of Baltimore County, with staff provided by these entities.
stakeholders: Residents, ratepayers, water and wastewater employees, and local governments in Baltimore City and Baltimore County.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but the development of a regional water governance model could potentially improve water management and stability, indirectly benefiting small businesses.

Title: Forest Conservation Act – Modifications
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "qualified conservation" for purposes of provisions of law related to forest mitigation banks; requiring the Department of Natural Resources to update a certain model local government ordinance by July 1, 2025, and adopt certain regulations relating to forest conservation on or before July 1, 2026; providing that a solar voltaic facilities granted a certificate of public convenience and necessity before July 1, 2023, may not be subject to certain afforestation requirements; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the Forest Conservation Act by redefining 'qualified conservation', adjusting rules for forest mitigation, and delaying certain requirements related to solar photovoltaic facilities and forest conservation plans. It also mandates updates to state and local regulations and manuals to align with these changes.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Developers, local governments, environmental conservation groups, and communities impacted by forest retention and development projects.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's adjustments to forest conservation requirements and delays in implementation may reduce compliance costs and regulatory burdens for small businesses involved in development projects.

Title: Bay Restoration Fund - Use of Funds - Municipal Wastewater Facilities - Sunset Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing the termination date for certain provisions of law that expand the authorized uses of the Bay Restoration Fund to include certain costs associated with the connection of a property using an on-site sewage disposal system to a certain existing municipal wastewater facility.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the sunset date for provisions that expand the use of the Bay Restoration Fund to include costs related to connecting properties with on-site sewage systems to municipal wastewater facilities, and clarifies the funding and program details for such projects.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment and local government agencies involved in water and sewer management.
stakeholders: Homeowners with on-site sewage disposal systems, local governments, environmental agencies, and residents in areas affected by water quality improvements.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions could help reduce small business failures by providing financial assistance and technical support for upgrading sewage systems, which can be a significant expense for small property owners and local governments.

Title: Real Property Assessments - Notice of Change in Value or Classification - Time Period
Synopsis: Increasing, for taxable year 2024, the time period after which a failure to send a notice of change in value or classification creates an irrebuttable presumption that the prior value or classification of certain real property has not changed.
bill_summary: The bill extends the time period for which a failure to send a notice of change in real property value or classification creates an irrebuttable presumption that the value has not changed. Specifically, it increases the deadline from 30 days after January 1 to May 1 for the taxable year beginning after June 30, 2024, but before July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: Property owners and local government assessors in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's extension of the notice period may reduce disputes and errors in property assessments, potentially lowering the risk of property tax-related issues for small businesses.

Title: Maryland Children's Health Program - Eligibility and Administration
Synopsis: Altering the eligibility requirements for the Maryland Children's Health Program; and repealing the requirement that the Program be administered, based on the family income of eligible individuals, through the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and managed care organizations or the MCHP premium plan.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the eligibility requirements for the Maryland Children’s Health Program, increasing the family income threshold from 200% to 300% of the federal poverty guidelines, and repeals certain administration requirements based on family income. It also establishes outreach and enrollment procedures, including school-based outreach and expedited eligibility.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children under 19 years old and their families in Maryland, especially those with family incomes up to 300% of the federal poverty guidelines.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on expanding health coverage and streamlining enrollment processes is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Horse Racing - Racing Facility Ownership and Construction - Racing Operations
Synopsis: Altering the location, type, and ownership of horse racing facilities that the Maryland Stadium Authority is authorized to finance; increasing the amount of debt that the Maryland Stadium Authority may issue for certain purposes in connection with certain racing facilities; requiring the Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority to prepare certain financial statements; requiring the Authority to submit a copy of any lease of the Pimlico racing facility to the Legislative Policy Committee for review and comment; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the financing, construction, and management of horse racing facilities in Maryland, including the transfer of ownership of the Pimlico Race Course, and establishes programs for community development, workforce housing, and economic support related to horse racing.
responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority and Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority
stakeholders: Horse racing industry, local communities near Pimlico, Laurel Park, and Bowie Race Course, small businesses, and residents of Prince George's County and Baltimore City
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides financial support, community development funds, and infrastructure investments aimed at stabilizing and supporting small businesses in the racing and surrounding communities.

Title: Maryland Stadium Authority - Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Special Funds - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Capital Works Fund and the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Emergency Repair Fund as special, nonlapsing funds to be administered by the Maryland Stadium Authority; providing that the purpose of the funds is to enable the Authority to pay all expenses related to capital improvements and repairs at the Camden Yards football sports facility; and requiring the transfer of certain amounts from a certain source into the funds.
bill_summary: The bill establishes two new funds, the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Capital Works Fund and the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Emergency Repair Fund, to finance capital improvements, repairs, and emergency repairs at the Camden Yards football stadium. It also allocates $5 million from bonds issued for the facility to each of these funds.
responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority
stakeholders: The Maryland Stadium Authority and the community surrounding Camden Yards, including sports fans and local residents.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small businesses or their failure rates; it focuses on stadium infrastructure funding.

Title: Maryland Protecting Opportunities and Regional Trade (PORT) Act
Synopsis: Establishing the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program and the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Fund; authorizing the Secretary of Labor to exempt an individual from the requirement to be actively seeking work for unemployment insurance benefits eligibility; requiring the Maryland Department of Labor and the Department of Commerce to establish certain temporary relief programs to provide assistance to individuals and certain entities impacted by a certain closure of the Port of Baltimore; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program and Fund to provide tuition assistance to dependents or spouses of transportation workers who died after January 1, 2022, due to work-related accidents. It also creates temporary relief programs for individuals and businesses affected by the reduced operations of the Port of Baltimore following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge, including financial aid and support for workforce retention.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Dependents and spouses of fallen transportation workers, individuals and businesses impacted by reduced Port operations, workers at the Port of Baltimore, small businesses, trade associations, and companies contracting with the Port.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides temporary financial assistance and support programs aimed at helping businesses and workers affected by the Port's reduced operations, which could help prevent business failures during this crisis.

Title: Electricity and Gas - Retail Supply - Regulation and Consumer Protection
Synopsis: Altering a certain charge that may be assessed to a public service company; providing for the recovery of certain costs through rates; establishing an energy salesperson license for certain persons that offer or sell electricity supply agreements or gas supply agreements to customers in the State; establishing an energy vendor license for certain persons that provide energy sales services in the State; prohibiting a certain electricity supplier from marketing electricity as green power unless certain conditions are met; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates regulations for electricity and gas retail supply in Maryland, including licensing requirements for energy salespersons and vendors, consumer protections, disclosure requirements, green power standards, and the establishment of a new division within the Public Service Commission to handle complaints and enforcement.
responsible_party: The Maryland Public Service Commission
stakeholders: Residential and small commercial electricity and gas consumers, energy salespersons, energy vendors, electricity and gas suppliers, and environmental groups involved in renewable energy.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve consumer protections, transparency, and market regulation, which could help small energy businesses succeed by creating clearer rules and enforcement mechanisms.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Expungement - Vendor Contracts
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to include system upgrades required to allow for automated expungement of charges and partial expungement of charges in any vendor contracts being negotiated at a certain time.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes individuals to file for partial expungement of charges even if other related charges are not eligible, and requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to include system upgrades for automated expungement in vendor contracts.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Individuals seeking expungement of criminal charges in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill mandates system upgrades for automated expungement, which could streamline processes and reduce administrative failures, potentially lowering small business failure related to legal and administrative issues.

Title: Failure to Pay Rent Proceedings - Shielding of Court Records
Synopsis: Requiring the District Court to shield all court records within 60 days after the final resolution of a failure to pay rent proceeding that did not result in a judgment of possession; authorizing the District Court, on motion of a tenant, to shield all court records relating to a failure to pay rent proceeding that results in a judgment of possession under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Judiciary to develop and publish on its website a certain form; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits landlords from increasing rent solely because a tenant has a failure to pay rent judgment and establishes procedures for shielding court records related to failure to pay rent proceedings, especially those that did not result in a judgment of possession, to protect tenants' records.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Tenants involved in failure to pay rent proceedings in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts tenants and the court system, with indirect effects on landlords. It does not directly target small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Board of License Commissioners
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor, rather than the Mayor and the President of the City Council of Baltimore City, to appoint the members of the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City with the advice and consent of the Senate; authorizing the Governor, rather than the Mayor and the President of the City Council of Baltimore City, to remove a member of the Board for certain infractions; requiring certain members of the Board to be residents of the City or to have served in City government for a minimum of 5 years immediately preceding the appointment; etc.
bill_summary: The bill reforms the appointment, removal, and operational rules of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners, including changing the appointment authority to the Governor, setting residency and experience requirements for members and employees, and aligning ethics and conflict of interest rules with state standards.
responsible_party: Maryland Governor's Office and the Maryland State Ethics Commission
stakeholders: Businesses involved in the manufacture, distribution, and sale of alcoholic beverages in Baltimore City, and residents of Baltimore City
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions on ethics, conflict of interest, and appointment processes aim to create a more transparent and stable regulatory environment, which could help reduce small business failures related to licensing and regulatory issues.

Title: More Opportunities for Career–Focused Students Act of 2024
Synopsis: Requiring each public high school to inform students of certain employment and skills training opportunities in the same manner the school informs students of postsecondary educational options; requiring, when informing certain students about certain career opportunities, each public high school to highlight opportunities in high-skilled careers that do not require completion of a college degree and are in high demand; and requiring a county board to assist public high schools in completing the requirements of the Act.
bill_summary: The bill promotes career-focused education by recognizing vocational certificates, industry certifications, and apprenticeships as equivalent to postsecondary education. It requires Maryland public high schools to inform students about employment and skills training opportunities, and to facilitate student authorization to share their information with apprenticeship sponsors and employers. The bill also mandates the use of a platform to support these initiatives and provides funding for apprenticeship entrance and industrial certification exams.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education and local county school boards
stakeholders: Public high school students in Maryland, especially those interested in vocational training, apprenticeships, and employment opportunities
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill encourages high school students to pursue high-demand, high-skill careers through apprenticeships and certifications, which can lead to better job placement and business growth, potentially reducing small business failure rates.

Title: Prince George's County - Alcoholic Beverages - License Renewal
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County to extend the deadline by which a holder of an alcoholic beverages license must file an application for renewal; and extending the expiration date for certain licenses issued by the Board to July 1, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners to extend renewal deadlines for alcoholic beverage licenses and adjusts the expiration date for certain licenses. It also provides a grace period for licenses that were not renewed between March 5, 2020, and December 31, 2023.
responsible_party: Prince George's County Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders in Prince George's County, including bars, restaurants, and liquor stores.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill reduces the risk of small business failure by providing extended renewal deadlines and a grace period for licenses that were not renewed on time, helping businesses avoid license suspension or revocation.

Title: Hospitals - Care of Infants After Discharge (Safe Sleep Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Requiring a hospital to take certain actions relating to the care of infants as soon as practicable before the hospital discharges an infant after the birth of the infant, including providing oral and written educational resources to the parent or legal guardian on how to provide a safe sleep environment and providing a list of resources available for an infant's parent or legal guardian; requiring each hospital, by January 1, 2025, to establish a process for providing and confirming the receipt of the educational resources; etc.
bill_summary: The bill mandates the development and implementation of a public awareness campaign about safe sleep practices for infants, establishes the Maryland Safe Sleep Certification Program for child care centers, hospitals, and birthing centers, and requires hospitals to provide educational resources to parents about safe sleep environments for infants before discharge.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Infants, parents, legal guardians, child care centers, hospitals, birthing centers, local health departments
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill introduces a certification program for child care centers, hospitals, and birthing centers, which could increase operational standards and compliance costs, but also potentially improve safety and reputation, thereby supporting business sustainability.

Title: Legally Protected Health Care - Gender-Affirming Treatment
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "legally protected health care" to include certain gender-affirming treatment, including medications and supplies, for the purposes of certain provisions of law that prohibit health occupations disciplinary actions and certain actions in criminal and civil proceedings and the use of certain resources in furtherance of certain investigations and proceedings related to legally protected health care.
bill_summary: The bill expands the definition of 'legally protected health care' to include gender-affirming treatments and medications, and restricts the use of state resources and legal actions related to such treatments, ensuring protections for providers and patients involved in gender-affirming care.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Health and relevant health occupations boards
stakeholders: Individuals receiving or providing gender-affirming treatment, including transgender and gender non-conforming persons, healthcare providers, and legal entities involved in health care and legal proceedings
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions primarily focus on legal protections and resource restrictions related to gender-affirming care, which may indirectly support healthcare providers and small clinics offering such services, potentially reducing legal and operational risks.

Title: Office of the Correctional Ombudsman - Establishment and Funding
Synopsis: Establishing the Office of the Correctional Ombudsman; authorizing the Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board to make a recommendation for the distribution of money from the Performance Incentive Grant Fund to the Office for fiscal year 2025 only; requiring the Office to conduct investigations, reviews, and assessments of administrative acts taken by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, by the Department of Juvenile Services, or in relation to individuals confined by either department; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Office of the Correctional Ombudsman within the Office of the Attorney General to investigate and review administrative acts by correctional and juvenile facilities, refer matters for criminal or disciplinary action, and improve oversight and accountability. It also transfers the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit into this new office and sets funding and staffing provisions.
responsible_party: Office of the Correctional Ombudsman within the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Individuals confined in correctional and juvenile facilities, their families, correctional and juvenile facility staff, and oversight agencies.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's primary focus is on oversight and investigation of correctional and juvenile facilities, with no direct programs aimed at small business failure reduction.

Title: Workgroup to Study Funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup to Study Funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility to identify and examine existing funding sources that support the Facility and study whether increased funding could enhance operations at the Facility, the funding sources of comparable facilities in the region, and available and potential federal, State, and local funding sources for the Facility; and requiring the Workgroup to report, on or before December 1, 2024, its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to study funding options for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility, including current funding sources, potential for increased funding, and comparisons with similar facilities in the region. The workgroup will make recommendations by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment and the designated members of the workgroup, including state and local officials.
stakeholders: The Westernport community, local government, and regional wastewater treatment facilities.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on funding for a wastewater treatment facility may indirectly support the operational stability of local businesses by ensuring proper wastewater management, but it does not directly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems - Reemployment
Synopsis: Clarifying a certain exemption from a certain reemployment offset for retirees of the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System who are reemployed by a local school system under certain conditions; and providing for the retroactive application of the Act to certain retirees who were reemployed by the Harford County Board of Education.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies rules regarding reemployment of retirees from the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System, including conditions under which their retirement allowances are exempt from reduction when reemployed by local school systems, and makes the provisions retroactive to certain retirees reemployed after January 1, 2020.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Retired teachers from the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System, local school systems, and the Maryland School for the Deaf
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Qualifying Nonprofit Organizations - Training and Reentry Services - Funding
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation of $1,000,000 in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2026 through 2028 to provide operating grants to certain qualifying nonprofit organizations for the purpose of providing training in automotive repair to incarcerated or formerly incarcerated individuals; and requiring the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services to administer the grant funds.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland government to allocate $1,000,000 annually from 2026 to 2028 to fund grants for nonprofit organizations that provide automotive repair training and reentry services to incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals, with a focus on employment placement.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals seeking employment in automotive repair, nonprofit organizations providing reentry services, and the automotive repair industry.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program aims to support nonprofit organizations that provide automotive repair training, which could help reduce small business failure by increasing skilled labor and employment opportunities.

Title: Prince George's County - Public School Employees Property Tax Credit and Office of Integrity and Compliance PG 503-24
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of Prince George's County to grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on dwellings that are owned by certain eligible employees of the Prince George's County Public School System; requiring the Prince George's County government to submit a certain report concerning the credit to certain persons on or before a certain date; providing that the Office of Integrity and Compliance is an independent unit within the school system; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Prince George's County to grant a property tax credit to eligible public school employees who own a dwelling in the county, and establishes an Office of Integrity and Compliance within the local school system to oversee accountability and investigations.
responsible_party: Prince George's County government and the Office of Integrity and Compliance within the Prince George's County Public School System.
stakeholders: Public school employees in Prince George's County and the local school system.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but the establishment of the Office of Integrity and Compliance aims to improve accountability and reduce fraud, which could indirectly benefit local businesses.

Title: State Procurement - Preferred Provider Requirements - Waiver
Synopsis: Authorizing the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers to grant a waiver from a certain requirement to use a certain preferred provider for the procurement of supplies and services under certain circumstances; requiring the Committee to review a certain request for a certain waiver to the State or a State aided or controlled entity under certain circumstances; and requiring Maryland Correctional Enterprises to report the length of time between each order and delivery of supplies and services for each fiscal year.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Department of General Services to grant waivers to state entities from the requirement to purchase supplies and services from Maryland Correctional Enterprises if the price is at least 10% above market rates or delivery times do not meet needs. It also establishes a committee to oversee preferred providers, including Blind Industries and Services of Maryland and Employment Works Program providers, to ensure fair pricing, create work opportunities for individuals with disabilities, and review procurement practices.
responsible_party: Department of General Services and the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers
stakeholders: State agencies, individuals with disabilities, community service providers, and businesses involved in procurement and employment programs for individuals with disabilities
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve procurement practices and support employment opportunities for individuals with disabilities, which could help small businesses and community providers succeed by providing fair pricing and procurement preferences.

Title: Department of Aging - Caregiver Expense Grant Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Caregiver Expense Grant Program in the Department of Aging to award grants to certain caregivers for up to 30% of the qualified expenses that exceed $2,000 paid or incurred by the caregiver to provide care or support to certain qualified family members; and authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of up to $5,000,000 to the Program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Caregiver Expense Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Aging, providing grants to eligible caregivers for qualified expenses related to caring for certain family members. It also allows caregivers to claim a tax credit against Maryland income tax based on these expenses.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
stakeholders: Caregivers and their qualified family members who require assistance and support
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, focusing instead on caregiver support and tax credits.

Title: University System of Maryland - Board of Regents - Membership
Synopsis: Requiring that certain appointing officials in making appointments to the Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland ensure that one member of the Board is a graduate of a historically Black college or university in the University System of Maryland; and applying the Act only after the next vacancy occurs on the Board of Regents after July 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill requires that when appointing members to the University System of Maryland's Board of Regents, appointing officials must ensure that at least one member is a graduate of a historically Black college or university within the system.
responsible_party: The Governor of Maryland, in conjunction with the Senate and House of Delegates, is responsible for appointing members to the Board of Regents.
stakeholders: Members of the University System of Maryland, historically Black colleges and universities within Maryland, and the broader Maryland community involved in higher education.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates or related programs.

Title: Economic Development – Maryland Economic Development Commission – Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain requirements relating to industry representation on the Maryland Economic Development Commission and the purpose of the Commission; repealing a requirement that the Office of International Trade make a certain report to the Commission; and repealing a requirement that the Maryland Tourism Development Board submit certain plans to the Commission.
bill_summary: The bill makes changes to the Maryland Economic Development Commission, including altering industry representation requirements, repealing certain reporting obligations, and clarifying the Commission's roles in strategic planning and review of tourism and international trade activities.
responsible_party: Maryland Economic Development Commission and related state agencies such as the Maryland Department of Commerce, Maryland Technology Development Corporation, Maryland Port Administration, and Maryland Tourism Development Board.
stakeholders: Businesses and industries across Maryland, including the life sciences, manufacturing, tourism, and international trade sectors, as well as the general population of Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on strategic planning, industry representation, and review of economic development activities is likely to support small business growth and reduce failure rates.

Title: Emergency Medical Services - Paramedics - Immunization Administration - Effective Date
Synopsis: Delaying the effective date to January 1, 2030, of certain provisions of law that repeal the authority of paramedics to administer influenza and COVID-19 immunizations under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill delays the effective date of laws that allow paramedics to administer influenza and COVID-19 immunizations under certain conditions, extending the date from 2025 to 2030.
responsible_party: Maryland State EMS Board and related health departments
stakeholders: Paramedics, public safety personnel, and the general public receiving immunizations in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's delay in implementing paramedic immunization authority may reduce immediate operational changes for small health-related businesses, but it does not directly target small business failure.

Title: Maryland Military Installation Council - Membership
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Maryland Military Installation Council to include the Maryland Secretary of Labor or a designee, the State Superintendent of Schools or a designee, and the President of the Military Alliance Council of Charles County; and increasing the number of members selected by the Governor from 5 to 6 and requiring that at least one is a spouse of a service member.
bill_summary: This bill amends the membership structure of the Maryland Military Installation Council, including the addition of new members and specific representation requirements, to enhance the council's effectiveness in supporting military installations in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Military Installation Council and the Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
stakeholders: Military communities, veterans, and residents near military installations in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on military installation support and community representation.

Title: Workers' Compensation - Failure to Insure - Penalties
Synopsis: Increasing, from $10,000 to $25,000, the cap on penalties for an employer's failure to secure required workers' compensation insurance or comply with an order of the State Workers' Compensation Commission regarding an employer's failure to secure required workers' compensation insurance.
bill_summary: The bill increases the penalties for employers in Maryland who fail to secure workers' compensation insurance for their employees. It authorizes the Workers' Compensation Commission to issue orders, hold hearings, and impose fines up to $25,000 for noncompliance, including penalties for failure to pay fines. The bill also makes corporate officers and LLC members liable if the employer is unable to pay.
responsible_party: Maryland Workers' Compensation Commission
stakeholders: Employers in Maryland, especially those who are noncompliant with workers' compensation insurance requirements, and their employees.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on penalties for noncompliance rather than direct support for small businesses, so its impact on reducing small business failure is minimal.

Title: Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending to December 31, 2030, the termination date of the Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date of the Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program in Maryland to December 31, 2030, ensuring continued state support for eligible Medicare beneficiaries' prescription drug costs.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Medicare beneficiaries in Maryland who are eligible for the program, particularly seniors with limited income
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program is designed to support seniors with prescription drug costs, which can help reduce financial strain and prevent small business failures among this population by alleviating healthcare expenses.

Title: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists – Quorum, Examination, and Apprenticeships
Synopsis: Clarifying that a quorum of the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists consists of a majority of appointed members; altering the circumstances under which an applicant for licensure is qualified to take the examination by adding completion of an apprenticeship approved by the Board as an alternative to obtaining experience in an environmental health specialist-in-training program; and authorizing the Board to approve an examination provider to administer the examination.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies the composition of the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists, updates licensure examination requirements to include apprenticeships as an alternative to training programs, and authorizes the Board to approve examination providers.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Board of Environmental Health Specialists
stakeholders: Environmental health professionals, aspiring environmental health specialists, and the public who rely on environmental health services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for apprenticeships and approved training programs aim to streamline licensure pathways, potentially reducing barriers for small businesses and individual practitioners in the environmental health field.

Title: Cemeteries - Burial-Transit Permits - Required Information
Synopsis: Requiring a person in charge of a cemetery to write on a burial-transit permit, the date of final disposition, the name and physical address of the cemetery, the burial, inurnment or scattering section and the lot and space number, or if the body or fetus was cremated and a certain authorizing agent takes control of the cremains, the name and address of the authorizing agent and the authorizing agent's relationship to the deceased or fetus.
bill_summary: The bill updates requirements for burial-transit permits in Maryland, including what information a cemetery must record and how permits are handled for final disposition, cremation, and disinterment.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health and the Secretary of Health.
stakeholders: Cemetery operators, funeral homes, and families involved in the final disposition of human remains.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill clarifies procedures and record-keeping for cemeteries and funeral providers, which may streamline operations and reduce legal or administrative errors that could lead to business failure.

Title: Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to June 1, 2034, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board in Maryland from 2024 to 2034, allowing the board to continue its functions and authority.
responsible_party: Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board and Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Employers, employees, and occupational safety and health professionals in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's extension of the advisory board's authority may support small businesses by providing ongoing guidance on safety regulations, potentially reducing compliance issues and failures.

Title: State Acupuncture Board – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Acupuncture Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Acupuncture Board in Maryland from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring its continued operation and regulatory authority.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health, specifically the State Acupuncture Board.
stakeholders: Licensed acupuncturists, patients receiving acupuncture services, and the general public seeking acupuncture care in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's extension of the Board's authority helps maintain regulatory oversight, which can support the stability and success of acupuncture small businesses.

Title: State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals from 2025 to 2030, continuing its authority and functions.
responsible_party: State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals within the Department of Health
stakeholders: Residential child care professionals and the children they serve in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: State Board of Dietetic Practice – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Dietetic Practice in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Board of Dietetic Practice from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring its continued existence and regulatory authority.
responsible_party: State Board of Dietetic Practice within the Department of Health
stakeholders: Dietitians, nutrition professionals, and the public who rely on regulated dietetic services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on extending the regulatory authority of the dietetic practice board and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the termination date of the State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring its continued operation and regulatory authority.
responsible_party: State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice in the Department of Health
stakeholders: Occupational therapists and individuals seeking occupational therapy services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure, but maintaining the regulatory board may support the stability of occupational therapy practices.

Title: State Board of Examiners in Optometry – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Examiners in Optometry in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Board of Examiners in Optometry from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring the continued existence and authority of the Board.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners in Optometry within the Department of Health
stakeholders: Optometrists, optometry patients, and the general public who require optometric services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's extension of the Board's authority helps maintain regulatory oversight, which can support the stability of optometry practices, potentially reducing small business failures in that sector.

Title: State Board of Examiners of Psychologists - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Examiners of Psychologists in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Board of Examiners of Psychologists from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring the continued existence and authority of the Board.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners of Psychologists within the Department of Health
stakeholders: Psychologists practicing in Maryland and individuals seeking psychological services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to a regulatory board for psychologists.

Title: State Board of Social Work Examiners - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Social Work Examiners in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Board, by December 1, 2024, to report to certain committees of the General Assembly information from the preceding 6-month period on processing times for license issuance and renewal, complaint resolution times, and the rate of compliance with certain requirements.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date of the State Board of Social Work Examiners from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2028, and requires the Board to report certain operational data to legislative committees before December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: State Board of Social Work Examiners in the Department of Health
stakeholders: Social workers, licensing applicants, and the general public in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure or economic development; it focuses on licensing and regulatory oversight of social workers.

Title: State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists - Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee within the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2026, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Committee.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee within the Maryland State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists
stakeholders: Behavior analysts, therapists, and clients receiving behavioral health services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but by extending the advisory committee, it may support the stability and regulation of behavioral health practices, indirectly benefiting small behavioral health businesses.

Title: Maryland Community Health Resources Commission – Sunset Extension and Program Evaluation
Synopsis: Adding the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission to the governmental activities and units subject to the Maryland Program Evaluation Act; and extending the termination date to June 30, 2035, for certain provisions of law related to the Commission.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission to 2035, adds the Commission to the Maryland Program Evaluation Act for review, and mandates an evaluation of the Commission by 2025.
responsible_party: Office of Program Evaluation and Government Accountability in the Department of Legislative Services
stakeholders: Community health organizations and residents seeking increased access to healthcare services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on community health resources and evaluation does not directly target small business failure rates, so the impact on small business failure is minimal.

Title: County Public Libraries - Minors, Children, and Teens - Prohibited Practices
Synopsis: Prohibiting a county public library from charging a fine for overdue library materials borrowed by a minor or intended for children or teens; prohibiting a county public library from charging a reserve fee for library materials reserved by a minor or intended for children or teens; prohibiting a county public library from prohibiting the borrowing of library materials by a minor or the borrowing of library materials intended for children or teens because of previous overdue library materials; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits Maryland county public libraries from charging fines, reserve fees, or replacement fees to minors or for materials intended for children and teens. It also prevents libraries from restricting borrowing based on overdue materials until 21 days after the due date, and mandates refunds for certain fees if materials are returned in good condition within specific timeframes.
responsible_party: Maryland county public libraries and their boards of trustees
stakeholders: Minors, children, and teens who borrow library materials from county public libraries in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Public Safety - 9-1-1 Trust Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the 9-1-1 Trust Fund to authorize the use of certain allocated funds for the payment of the salary of certain personnel.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the use of funds from the Maryland 9–1–1 Trust Fund to include paying the salaries of certain personnel involved in 9–1–1 services, in addition to existing purposes such as system enhancement, maintenance, and public education.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Public Safety, specifically the 9–1–1 Trust Fund administration, is responsible for implementing the programs.
stakeholders: Public safety answering points, emergency responders, and residents who rely on 9–1–1 services in Maryland.
